title: Thursday, 19th May, 2016

ACTION
Buy
Tesla Motors Inc. (TSLA)
Return Potential: 22%

PM

Putting in our reservation for the Model 3; upgrading TSLA to Buy

11:04 am
BE

Hm ..............

PM

Source of opportunity
We upgrade shares of Tesla to Buy from Neutral with 22% upside to our 6-month
price target of $250. While we believe the volume targets are ambitious, Street
and investor expectations seem more grounded and following a 23% decline in
the share price post the Model 3 unveil, we do not believe Tesla shares are fully
capturing the company’s disruptive potential. This combined with a more stable
macro backdrop (relative to January/February) and increased confidence in Model
3 demand (from orders and our competitive benchmarking) drives attractive
risk/reward. The company has publicly stated it might look to raise capital, and
our detailed capex analysis points to capital needs of $1bn.

PM

And then just a few hours later we get this...

11:09 am
PM

Here's William Lee from Citi

PM

April FOMC Minutes Resuscitate Possible Summer Rate Hikes A Bit
The April FOMC minutes were supposed to be a non-event, yet they succeeded in moving markets to raise the likelihood of a June or July rate increase by 20 percentage points. Although still low, the probabilities for a June or July rate increase are now non-negligible.
Notwithstanding such re-pricing, we believe the minutes continue to show a considerable range of views among FOMC participants—to the point of preventing any explicit wording about a prospective June rate increase in the policy statement. This contrasts with the October FOMC statement that said they determine "whether it will be appropriate to raise the target range at its next meeting." We will see if Chair Yellen is more successful in conveying the consensus view in upcoming speeches.

PM

Markets Scared Straight(er)—What Happened?
Market pricing for a June or July rate increase rose by approximately 20 percentage points, to 32 and 47 percent, respectively, shortly after the release of the April FOMC minutes. This surprisingly sharp increase in the probability of imminent rate hikes contrasts greatly with the 9 percentage point decline in the probability of a June hike after the release of the April FOMC statement three weeks ago.

Two statements in the April minutes are candidates for being the double-barrel "smoking gun" that caused market participants to "straighten up" their low-probability assessments of a June or July rate hike.

"Also, many participants noted that downside risks emanating from developments abroad, while reduced, still warranted close monitoring. For these reasons, participants generally saw maintaining the target range for the federal funds rate…. at this meeting and continuing to assess developments carefully as consistent with setting policy in a data-dependent manner and as leaving open the possibility of an increase in the federal funds rate at the June FOMC meeting."

11:10 am
PM

This was followed later in the text with the following:

"Most participants judged that if incoming data were consistent with economic growth picking up in the second quarter, labor market conditions continuing to strengthen, and inflation making progress toward the Committee's 2 percent objective, then it likely would be appropriate for the Committee to increase the target range for the federal funds rate in June.

However, this wording may misleadingly suggest agreement within the FOMC to raise rates in June. Insofar as there is any agreement, it is to the "boiler plate" statement that rates will rise when key data conditions are met. Yet, there is a considerable range of views among Committee participants about the exact configuration of data that would satisfy each (voting) member. This poses a formidable obstacle to Chair Yellen's ability to forge a consensus among the voting members for a June rate increase. A June or July rate increase is not likely unless a number of conditions were "right."

PM

April Statement and Minutes Missing Key Words: "appropriate…at its next meeting"
We agree the April minutes show that June is "on the table" for a potential rate hike—but June is not a "done deal." By comparison, the December rate hike was signaled as a "sure thing" in the October FOMC statement with the following phrase:

" In determining whether it will be appropriate to raise the target range at its next meeting, the Committee will assess progress--both realized and expected--toward its objectives of maximum employment and 2 percent inflation.

PM

The October policy statement was followed with statements in the October minutes that showed that the voting FOMC members were in agreement:

Members emphasized that this change was intended to convey the sense that, while no decision had been made, it may well become appropriate to initiate the normalization process at the next meeting, provided that unanticipated shocks do not adversely affect the economic outlook and that incoming data support the expectation that labor market conditions will continue to improve and that inflation will return to the Committee's 2 percent objective over the medium term.

There are key differences between the October and April minutes that show there is only a relatively weak conditional consensus for a June rate hike, compared with the much more unified views in October 2015 for the December increase. One key difference between the October 2015 and April 2016 minutes was that in October, the voting members thought it would be appropriate to initiate rate increases in December. By contrast, we see that only "most participants" favored a June 2016 hike. The latter includes non-voting FOMC participants, and likely does not include a large majority of voting members.

11:11 am
PM

What Will Make June or July More Likely Candidates For Rate Hikes?
The option for a June rate hike is open—but there are a number of hurdles that lower the chances. Apart from domestic developments, these obstacles include events abroad such as the pending referendum about the UK membership in the European Union, and China's exchange rate management.

Domestic developments that would increase the chances for a June or July rate hike span a wide range of indicators: (1) a persistent rebound in above-potential growth; (2) continued improvement in the labor market; and (3) evidence that inflation would rise at a sustained pace toward the Fed's target. These criteria face stiff challenges and high hurdle rates set by the dovish FOMC members (especially Chair Yellen and Governor Brainard).

PM

Yeah, there's a lot of grey there, but i think warranted

BE

Yeah, maybe. We're definitely in the territory where small amounts of Fedspeak need lots of conjecture and analysis.

11:26 am
BE

We initiate on Vedanta with a Neutral rating and a 12-month price target of 400p. Vedanta has a portfolio of attractive assets (zinc/power/oil). However, the key challenge remains significant debt pressure – exacerbated by recent lower commodity prices. The company has c.US$1.3 bn/year of maturities over the next 4 years – for which we estimate FCF generation and cash at subsidiaries is sufficient. However, if commodity prices slide further or if the company faces issues in upstreaming cash from its subsidiaries (particularly Cairn and Hindustan Zinc) it could entail fund raising and as such hamper the investment case.

BE

There. Done. Thanks again, Goldman. Second time today.

BE

Let me sum up the warning first.

PM

Welcome to ML

BE

Thomas Cook. When we last heard from TCG (21st March) the company warned that consumers are 'leaving it later to book this year' and so hitting consensus numbers is 'dependent on seeing a sustained recovery.” This morning the company has revised its EBIT guidance to between £310-335m: the midpoint is 6% lower than Bloomberg consensus of £343m and 5% lower than our forecast of £339m. Looking at the H1 16 results, H1 EBIT loss of £163m vs. £173m last year (vs. company complied consensus EBIT loss range of between £165m to £170m). Within the results there is a big mix disparity: Northern European trading is stronger than expected (EBIT +£17m YoY) but trading at the German Airline, Condor is particularly weak (EBIT -£19m YoY) due to demand weakness to Turkey and market overcapacity. Looking at the H116 Cash Flow, we note that Net Debt was £825m (vs. £700m this time last year). This reflects lower bookings and a materially weaker working capital position YoY. There was a £411m working capital outflow (vs. £176m last year): we await a further explanation around this at the analyst presentation but assume it is due to lower bookings, payment timings and changes to rules around deposits in Germany. In terms of the outlook, management state that 63% of the summer programme is sold (vs. 62% last year). We note that when we last heard from TCG, the company said that bookings were -5% given the volatile trading backdrop and that FY16 guidance was dependent on a recovery in customer confidence as TCG progresses through the year. While the EBIT guidance is now lower, there appears to not be a material shift in bookings (volumes -5% with strong pricing in Northern Europe, UK and soft trading in Germany, Belgium and Condor). Elsewhere, TCG plans to buy up to £100m of its bonds and it is worth noting that Moody’s recently assigned TCG a B1 rating (one notch higher). TCG is trading on a CY16 P/E of 8.8x falling to 7.0x in FY17.

11:30 am
BE

Note Egypt is highly profitable for Thomas Cook.

BE

BE

11:32 am
PM

Here's CS for completeness

PM

We now forecast a 3% LFL EBIT decline: H1 results were good and further re-fi has been achieved but slow booking trends
(down 5% YoY) impacted by geopolitical events in both source markets and destinations drives our 2016E EPS down 21%.
Our sub-sector preference remains for TUI (rated O/P) but we maintain our rating on Thomas Cook believing that key
changes in the business remain in evidence and support a 2015-18E EPS CAGR of 23% - although we fully acknowledge
EPS risk remains high.
 Geopolitical pressures drive significant downgrades: TCG has reported a better than expected H1 EBIT loss of £163m (vs
CSe £175m loss) but the impact of the Brussels attacks and material shift away from Turkey (we estimate bookings are
down 40-50%) leads the company to issue guidance for EBIT of £310-335m or £290-315m excluding a £20m fx tailwind vs
our previous estimate of £344m and consensus of £343m. The c£40m difference principally reflects around £10-15m from
weaker Belgian trading post the Brussels airport attack (Belgian 2015 EBIT £18m) and £20-25m from weakness in Condor
(the German airline), which is adapting to material schedule changes away from Turkey and broader competitive challenges
in a market facing high supply growth. We reduce our reported EBIT by 7% to £320m but with the impact of financial
leverage and by no longer assuming any pay down of high yield bonds, our EPS falls 21%. We assume this is partially oneoff
in nature so 2017E EBIT/EPS fall 3%/11% respectively.
 Target price lowered to 100p: We reduce our TP to 100p (from 135p) based on 11x 2016E EPS. We note many travel
companies are trading on historically cheap multiples (most notably the airlines) and hence we believe Thomas Cook
shares are likely to fall significantly today given the size of the EPS adjustments even though the share price has fallen 26%
YTD. Based on the 18 May close price, our new TP implies 12% potential upside and we leave our rating unchanged
although continue to prefer TUI AG noting it specifically held its guidance at H1 results last week for at least 10% EBIT
growth.

BE

And we're not going to speculate about Flight MS804, because there's enough of that elsewhere.

11:39 am
BE

So here's Investec on Fevertree, if only to shut me up.

BE

After four months of trading in FY16, Fever-Tree has announced that it
expects to materially exceed market expectations for the year. Continued
strong momentum and the annualised benefits from FY15 wins have
produced a strong ytd revenue performance, enhanced by currency-led gross
margin improvements. We upgrade PBT forecasts for FY16E by 18% and
FY17E by 16%. Our DCF-based TP increases to 840p and we reiterate our Buy
recommendation.

BE

 Fever-Tree has released a trading update, highlighting strong sales momentum
from 2015 has continued into 2016. Some of the uplift has come from the
annualised benefit of new distribution wins from 2H15, but otherwise there is no
one single trigger to this strong sales outperformance. Growth has been
delivered across both on-trade and off-trade channels, with further distribution
wins and continuing good rate of sales performance. It has also been spread
across a number of geographies, with the UK and Europe particularly delivering
better than expected growth. At present, we would anticipate a stronger rate of
revenue growth in 1H16 versus 2H16, given the timing of wins in FY15.
 Currency in the first 4 months of the year has also been favourable, with sterling
weakening against both the dollar and the Euro. As a result, the gross margin
delivery in this period has been better versus last year’s 1H (50.5%) and likely
to be more in line with 2H15 (53.2%). Both of these factors mean that the
company now expects to materially exceed previous market expectations.
 Our original forecast had suggested a FY16E revenue uplift of 20%, but we
increase this now to 33%. This suggests an additional £8m of sales. With an
increased gross margin assumption, this results in an increase in EBITDA
margin to over 31% versus our previous estimate of 29.7%. FY16E adjusted
PBT increases to £24.2m with EPS of 16.8p (from £20.5m, 14.1p) and FY17E
increases to £26.9m, EPS of 18.6p (from £23.1m, EPS 15.9p).
 Incorporating these upgrades into our DCF target price calculation sees this
increase from 740p to 840p. We reiterate our Buy recommendation.

The FY results were c.2% ahead of consensus at the PBT level, but in line with our forecasts. EPS was slightly further ahead of expectations on a lower tax rate. Transformation costs were higher than forecast in 2016, and management's guidance points to a higher than expected outturn in 2017 too. We see downward pressure on consensus as a result, albeit with potential mitigation if a lower tax rate can be sustained. We remain concerned about regulation, wages and pensions short term, and parcel trends that may be adverse to Royal Mail in the long term. Our recommendation remains SELL with a 360p target price.

Here's Jefferies.

BE

FY15/16 adjusted operating profit before transformation costs was relatively
stable, in line with expectations, with accelerated cost savings compensating
for increasing competition. The FY16/17E outlook is uncertain in view of
difficult comparatives, and dependent on a new pay deal and pension reforms.
We do not anticipate any changes to consensus expectations, but think the
shares will react negatively following recent 6% sector outperformance.
FY15/16 results in line with expectations. FY15/16 adjusted operating profit before
transformation costs was stable at £742m, 2% ahead of consensus £727m, mainly driven by
GLS. UKPIL adjusted operating profit decreased 1% to £608m (vs. consensus £607m), driven
by a 3.0% underlying addressed letter volume decline, parcel volume growth of 3.0%, partly
offset by negative price & mix effects of 2.0% and 1.0% lower operating expenses, following
£182m avoided costs, with all trends in line with earlier developments. GLS operating profit
increased 2% to £117m (5% ahead of consensus £111m), with volume growth of 10%, offset
by estimated divestment effects and negative currency factors, while profitability remained
stable at 7.4%. Adjusted operating profit after transformation costs decreased 2% to £551m
(vs. consensus £545m), while IFRS operating profit fell 37% to £294m, reflecting increased
IAS19R pension service charges. A dividend of 22.1p is being proposed (vs. consensus
21.7p), implying a yield of 4.4%.

11:58 am
BE

Outlook uncertain. The outlook for FY16/17E is uncertain, with Royal Mail flagging
slowing economic growth, difficult comparatives due to elections and the strong GLS
performance, increasing competitive pressures in Germany and the uncertain outcome of
labour negotiations and pension reforms. Cost avoidance is expected to lead to a similar
result in FY16/17E as in the prior year. Consensus estimates suggest operating profit will
remain relatively stable this year, an assumption we think is unlikely to change much ahead
of a pay deal and pension reforms.
Focus on pay deal and pension reforms. The FY16/17E earnings outlook depends
on the outcome of labour negotiations regarding a new pay deal and pension reforms.
Initial union proposals imply annual wage inflation of 3.7%, worse than our current 2.8%
assumption, while Royal Mail will also have to discuss pension reforms. Note that a 50bps
change to our wage inflation assumption changes EPS by 8% and our DCF valuation by 15%.
Ofcom review. Another upcoming catalyst will be the delayed Ofcom consultation
document, expected over the coming weeks, following a wider review of the regulation of
Royal Mail. We think this will likely be a negative catalyst, although earlier suggestions to
limit Royal Mail's commercial freedom by imposing price controls sound relatively harsh.
Valuation / risk factors
Despite wage and pension uncertainties, Royal Mail shares have outperformed the European
postal sector by 6% over the last six months and are trading at 7.6x FY17E adjusted EBIT,
broadly in line with the sector. Our DCF-based 400p price target assumes the costs of the
pension reforms will more than compensate the hidden value in the London development
property. Key risk factors include worsening e-substitution, increasing competition in
parcels, labour and pension reform discussions and regulatory uncertainty.
